comment.author: 87724873@N00
comment._content:
The date on the lower left side of the image says 6-11-13
I don't know what type of flying machine they're sitting in, but they certainly did not go anywhere in it. They were dressed for photo opps, not flying. :-)

comment.author: 42264328@N00
comment._content: It looks like there is something about this in the Smithsonian Arcihves, NATIONAL AIR AND SPACE ARCHIVES Ernest Jones Aeronautical Collection Accession XXXX-0096 (PDF), p. 21: L.A. "Jack" Vilas's flying boat, 1913, with portraits of F.J. Bersbach, H.F. McCormick and Vilas I'm not sure if that really adds any information! Harold McCormick seems to be: Harold Fowler McCormick (1872 – 1941) was chairman of the board of International Harvester Company. (Wikipedia article).

comment.author: 36899742@N00
comment._content: They do appear to be in Vilas's flying boat: www.aviationhalloffamewisconsin.com/inductees/vilas.htm

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: According to memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=hhdatapage&fileN... a Frank J Bersbach was the son of Alfred Bersbach, owner of a Wilmette Illinois house documented in the HABS survey. See hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/hhh.il0312

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Harold F McCormick left a collection of aeronautica to Princeton: diglib.princeton.edu/ead/getEad?eadid=C0496 He appears to have been one of the organizers of the first International Aviation Meet held in Grant Park, Illinois, in 1911 and the owner of a hydroplane built for him by Glenn Curtiss. So this may be his own plane.

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: Thanks to all for your research and information.  It does appear to be a photo of Jack Vilas's flying boat with Harold F. McCormick.  We will add the information to the source data and reload the description.

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harold_Fowler_McCormick en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_John_Bersbach,_Sr. The two families were married into each other.
